Award.AwardTitle: Variational Conditions: Analysis, Algorithms and Applications
Award.AbstractNarration: Lu<br/>DMS-0807893<br/><br/> The variational condition provides a unified mathematical<br/>model for a large number of equilibrium problems. It is also<br/>closely related to other mathematical problems such as<br/>optimization problems and complementarity problems. The<br/>investigator and her colleagues study the mathematical structure<br/>of certain finite-dimensional variational conditions, develop<br/>solution algorithms, and apply these to handle model input<br/>uncertainty in practice. Specifically, they investigate the<br/>influence of the major constraint qualifications on the structure<br/>of the variational condition, to identify conditions that<br/>indicate nice solution behavior and are more general than the<br/>current nondegeneracy condition. Based on these conditions, they<br/>analyze the sensitivity and stability of a variational condition<br/>with respect to perturbations in both the function and the set in<br/>its formulation, provide criteria to identify classes of<br/>practical problems that satisfy these conditions, and design and<br/>justify algorithms for solving these problems. They also apply<br/>knowledge gained in this work to other areas dealing with model<br/>input uncertainty, such as robust programming and stochastic<br/>optimization. <br/><br/> The investigator studies a mathematical model called<br/>variational condition. This is a general model that<br/>characterizes an equilibrium status. For example, it can model<br/>an economic equilibrium that predicts commodity prices, sector<br/>activities, and consumer consumptions, or a force equilibrium<br/>that describes the geometry and dynamics of a mechanical<br/>structure, or a traffic flow equilibrium in a transportation or<br/>computer network. Thus, this model provides a unified framework<br/>for a very large number of equilibrium problems from areas<br/>including economic policy studies, structural engineering,<br/>transportation, computer networks, materials science, and other<br/>areas. It is also closely related to some other important<br/>mathematical problems, such as optimization problems; it can be<br/>regarded as a generalization of optimization problems. In this<br/>project, the investigator and her colleagues seek to develop<br/>better insight into the mathematical structure of this problem,<br/>and to exploit this insight to produce better computational<br/>algorithms and the means for justifying them. They investigate<br/>what the solutions of this problem look like, how they change<br/>corresponding to changes in the model input, how to find a<br/>solution quickly and robustly, and how to identify practical<br/>problems that are easy to solve and have robust behavior. <br/>Success in the work helps to better understand, analyze and solve<br/>the broad class of equilibrium problems.
